speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the Federal Reserve, we are strongly committed to achieving the monetary policy goals that Congress has given us: maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since the beginning of the pandemic, we have taken forceful actions to provide relief and stability, to ensure that the recovery will be as strong as possible, and to limit lasting damage to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today my colleagues on the FOMC and I kept interest rates near zero and maintained our sizable asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These measures, along with our strong guidance on interest rates and our balance sheet, will ensure that monetary policy will continue to deliver powerful support to the economy until the recovery is complete.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The path of the economy continues to depend significantly on the course of the virus.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A resurgence in recent months in COVID-19 cases, hospitalizations, and deaths is causing great hardship for millions of Americans and is weighing on economic activity and job creation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Following a sharp rebound in economic activity last summer, the pace of the recovery has moderated in recent months, with the weakness concentrated in the sectors of the economy most adversely affected by the resurgence of the virus and by greater social distancing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Household spending on services remains low, especially in sectors that typically require people to gather closely, including travel and hospitality.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And household spending on goods has moderated following earlier large gains.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In contrast, the housing sector has more than fully recovered from the downturn, supported in part by low mortgage interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Business investment and manufacturing production have also picked up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The overall recovery in economic activity since last spring is due in part to federal stimulus payments and expanded unemployment benefits, which have provided essential support to many families and individuals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The recently enacted Coronavirus Response and Relief Act [Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021] will provide additional support.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall economic activity remains below its level before the pandemic, and the path ahead remains highly uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As with overall economic activity, the pace of improvement in the labor market has slowed in recent months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Employment fell by 140,000 in December, as continued gains in many industries were outweighed by significant losses in industries where the resurgence of the virus has weighed further on activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, the leisure and hospitality sector lost nearly half a million jobs, largely from restaurants and bars.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate remained elevated at 6.7 percent in December, and participation in the labor market is notably below pre-pandemic levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Although there has been much progress in the labor market since the spring, millions of Americans remain out of work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic downturn has not fallen equally on all Americans, and those least able to shoulder the burden have been the hardest hit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, the high level of joblessness has been especially severe for lower-wage workers in the service sector and for African Americans and Hispanics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic dislocation has upended many lives and created great uncertainty about the future.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The pandemic has also left a significant imprint on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Following large declines in the spring, consumer prices picked up over the summer but have leveled out more recently.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For those sectors that have been most adversely affected by the pandemic, prices remain particularly soft.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall, on a 12-month basis, inflation remains below our 2 percent longer-run objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While we should not underestimate the challenges we currently face, several developments point to an improved outlook for later this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sufficiently widespread vaccinations would enable us to put the pandemic behind us and return to more normal economic activities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the meantime, continued observance of social-distancing measures and wearing masks will help us reach that goal as soon as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Support from fiscal policy will help households and businesses weather the downturn as well as limit lasting damage to the economy that could otherwise impede the recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, as we have seen since last summer, the economy has proved more resilient than expected, in part reflecting the adaptability of households and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Finally, monetary policy is playing a key role in supporting the recovery and will continue to do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s response to this crisis has been guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people, along with our responsibilities to promote the stability of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today we unanimously reaffirmed our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy, as we typically do each January.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As we say in that statement, we view maximum employment as a “broad-based and inclusive goal.” Our ability to achieve maximum employment in the years ahead depends importantly on having longer-term inflation expectations well anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the Committee reiterated in today’s policy statement, with inflation running persistently below 2 percent, we will aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time so that inflation averages 2 percent over time and longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect to maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy until these employment and inflation outcomes are achieved.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With regard to interest rates, we continue to expect it will be appropriate to maintain the current 0 to ¼ percent target range for the federal funds rate until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee’s assessment of maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, we will continue to increase our holdings of Treasury securities by at least $80 billion per month and of agency mortgage-backed securities by at least $40 billion per month until substantial further progress has been made toward our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The increase in our balance sheet since last March has materially eased financial conditions and is providing substantial support to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economy is a long way from our employment and inflation goals, and it is likely to take some time for substantial further progress to be achieved.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our forward guidance for the federal funds rate, along with our balance sheet guidance, will ensure that the stance of monetary policy remains highly accommodative as the recovery progresses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our guidance is outcome based and ties the path of the federal funds rate and the balance sheet to progress toward reaching our employment and inflation goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thus, if progress toward our goals were to slow, the guidance would convey our intention to increase policy accommodation through a lower expected path of the federal funds rate and a higher expected path of the balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall, our interest rate and balance sheet tools are providing powerful support to the economy and will continue to do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve also taken actions to more directly support the flow of credit in the economy, deploying our emergency lending powers to an unprecedented extent, enabled in large part by financial backing and support from Congress and the Treasury.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Although the CARES Act facilities are no—are no longer open to new activity, our other facilities remain in place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to using our full range of tools to support the economy and to help assure that the recovery from this difficult period will be as robust as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I look forward to your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on, on your first question, I don’t want to comment on a particular company or, or day’s market activity or things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just not really something that I would typically comment on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of macroprudential policy tools, so, as you know, no doubt, we rely on sort of always-on, through-the-cycle macroprudential policy tools, particularly the stress tests and also the elevated levels of liquidity and capital and, and, and also resolution planning that we—that we impose on the largest financial institutions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t use time-varying tests and tools as some other countries do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think it’s a good approach because—for us to use ones that are always-on—because we don’t really think we’d be successful in every case in picking the exact right time to intervene in markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s for banks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You really asked about nonbanks, the nonbank sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we monitor financial conditions very broadly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And while we don’t have jurisdiction over, over many areas in the nonbank sector, other agencies do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we do coordinate through the Financial Stability Oversight Council and with other agencies who have responsibility for, for nonbank supervision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, in fact, as you know, in the last crisis, the banking system held up fairly well so far.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and the dislocations that we saw from the outsized economic and financial shock of the pandemic really appeared in the nonbank sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s—right now we are engaged in, in carefully examining, understanding, and thinking about what, what in the nonbank sector will need to be addressed in the next year or so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess I’d start by saying that the, the fiscal response that we’ve seen to this downturn has been strong, and I think we can say now that it’s been sustained after the passage of the—of the, the most recent act in, in late December.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s really a key reason why the recovery has been as strong as it’s been.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Fiscal policy has been absolutely essential.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When we look back on, on the history of this period, we’ll see a strong and sustained fiscal policy response.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would—I would add that we’re, as I mentioned, a long way from a full recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Something like 9 million people remain unemployed as a consequence of the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s as many people as lost their jobs at the peak of the Global Financial Crisis and the Great Recession.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many small businesses are under pressure, and there are other needs to be addressed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the path ahead is still pretty uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, all of that said, the judgment on how much to spend and in what way is really one for Congress and the Administration and not for the Fed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And these discussions are going on right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s a discussion, as you know, right now around, around those precise questions, and, and that’s appropriate, but not for us to play a role in talking about specific policies.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let me—let me provide a little context.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The shock that the—from the pandemic was unprecedented both in its nature and in its size and in the amount of unemployment that it created and in the shock to economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s nothing close to it in our modern economic history.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So our response was really to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we—we’ve done what we could, first, to restore market function and to provide a bit of relief, then to support the recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, hopefully, we’ll be able to do the third thing, which is to avoid longer-run damage to the—to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our role assigned by Congress is maximum employment and stable prices and also look after financial stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in a world where, almost a year later, we’re, we’re still 9 million jobs, at least—that’s one way of counting it; it can actually be counted much higher than that—short of maximum employment and people are out of the labor force who were in the labor force—the real unemployment rate is close to 10 percent if you include people that’ve left the labor force—it’s very much appropriate that monetary policy be highly accommodative to support maximum employment and price stability, which is getting inflation back to 2 percent and averaging 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on, on matters of financial stability, we have a framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t look at one thing or two things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We look at—and we made that framework public after the financial crisis so that it could be criticized and understood and we could be held accountable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, the things that we look at are—we do look at asset prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also look at leverage in the banking system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We look at leverage in the non—the nonbanking system, which is to say, corporates and households.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we look at also funding risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if you look at it across that range of, of, of readings, they’re each different, but we monitor them carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would say that financial stability vulnerabilities overall are moderate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our overall goal is to assure that the financial system itself is resilient to, to shocks of all kinds, that it’s strong and resilient.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that includes not just the banks, but money market funds and, and all different kinds of nonbank financial structures as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So when we get to the nonfinancial sector, we don’t—we don’t have jurisdiction over that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But—so I would just say that our—that there are many things that go in, as you know, to, to setting asset prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you look at what’s really been driving asset prices, really, in the last couple of months, it isn’t monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s been expectations about vaccines.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s also financial—sorry, fiscal policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those are—those are the news items that have been driving, driving asset purchases—sorry, asset values in, in recent months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I know that monetary policy does play a role there, but that’s how we look at it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think, you know, I think that the connection between low interest rates and, and asset values is probably something that’s not as tight as people think, because a lot of—a lot of different factors are driving asset prices at any given time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, that’s—as you know, that’s one of the very difficult questions in all of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we don’t rule it out as a theoretical matter, but we, we clearly look to macroprudential tools, regulatory tools, supervisory tools, other kinds of tools rather than monetary policy in, in addressing financial stability issues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not—you know, the, the monetary policy we know strengthens economic activity and job creation through fairly well-understood channels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And a strong economy is actually a great supporter of financial stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That will mean strong, you know, well-capitalized institutions, and, and households will be—will be working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and so we know that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think that’s unresolved.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I, I think it’s, it’s something we, we look at as not, not theoretically ruled out but not something we, we—we’ve ever done and not something we would plan to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We would rely on macroprudential and other tools to deal with financial stability issues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on inflation, a couple of things—there are a couple of things that are worth mentioning.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One is just that we know that we measure inflation on a trailing 12-month basis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And as we—as we lap the very low inflation readings of March and April of last year, we’ll see measured 12-month inflation move up a few tenths.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is just—they’re called base effects, and, and that’s a—that’s a transient thing that we think will pass.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s also the possibility—indeed, it’s in some forecasts—that as the economy fully reopens, there’ll be a burst of spending, and—because people will be enthusiastic that the pandemic is over, potentially, and that that could also create some upward pressure on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, again, we would see that as something likely to be transient and not to be very large.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In both cases, we don’t see those as either lasting or particularly large.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the way we would react is, we’re going to be patient.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Expect us to wait and see and not react if we see small and what we would review—we would view as very likely to be transient effects on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think if you—you know, it helps to look back at, at the inflation dynamics that the United States has had now for some decades and notice that there has been, you know, significant disinflationary pressure for some time, for a couple of decades.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation has averaged less than 2 percent for a quarter of a century.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the inflation dynamics, with the flat Phillips curve and low persistence of inflation, is very much intact.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those things, they change over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We understand that inflation dynamics evolve constantly over time, but they don’t change rapidly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we think it’s very unlikely that anything we see now would result in, you know, troubling inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, if we did get sustained inflation at a level that was uncomfortable, we have tools for that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s far harder to deal with, with too low inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know what to do with higher inflation, which is, you know, should the need arise, we, we would have those tools.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we don’t expect to see that at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of how much, you know, what we’ve said is we’d like to see—because inflation has been running persistently below 2 percent, we’d like to see it run moderately above 2 percent for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have not adopted a formula.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not going to adopt a formula.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to—we, we use policy rules and formulas in everything we do, consult them constantly, but we don’t set policy by them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we’re going to preserve an element of judgment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, we’ll seek inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll, we’ll show what that means when we get inflation above 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The, the way to achieve credibility on that is to actually do it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so that’s what we’re planning on doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see that we’re, we’re vaccinating people and at a rate of about a million a day, apparently, and that it’ll take quite a while to get—to get to the numbers that the experts say are required to get to herd immunity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think it’s going to be a struggle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’ll notice that we, we said that the, the pandemic still, still provides considerable downside risks to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s one of the reasons why, is that—is the slowness of the rollout.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The other—another reason why is just the arrival of these new virus strains.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t know how to—we don’t know how to model that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we can have a base case, but we realize no one knows how the—how this new vaccine will roll out, how successful it will be, how high we’ll be able to drive vaccination, and those sorts of things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we have a base case, and we—but we always—we always look at, at the range of possibilities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In this case, we particularly look at the downside risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, that’s really what we do is, we, we set policies so that we’re, we’re, you know, we’re going to remain accommodative until we actually see improvement in the economy and not just in the outlook, in the data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s how we think about, about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would—I would also add, there’s nothing more important to the economy now than, than people getting vaccinated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, if you—if you, you think about the places where the economy is weak—I mentioned bars and restaurants.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s 400,000 jobs we lost last month, and that’s all because of the spread of the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many other areas of the economy—actually, there was actually job creation in—you know, in goods production and in some service parts—industries as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we’re just not going to be able to get that last group of people back to work—and it’s a big group of people—until we get the pandemic behind us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we have not won this yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven’t succeeded in doing this yet, and we need to stay focused on it as a country and, and get there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we clearly can, but we’re going to have to stay focused.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that includes—you know, that includes us at the Fed, monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I have been vaccinated once, and I expect to get my second vaccine sometime soon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No, we haven’t—we haven’t done that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, remember, we’re, we’re focused on maximum employment, price stability, financial stability as I defined it—the broad financial sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and that—that’s not, you know—over the years, we, we consult the fact that we have that authority.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, no, it’s not something we’re looking at right now at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, first, I—we, we think our policy stance is, is just right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think it’s providing significant support for economic activity and hiring.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, you know, we, we adopted a new monetary policy framework of flexible average inflation targeting in August.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In September, we, we implemented rate guidance that, that was consistent with and based on that new framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In December, we did the same for asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we now have, you know, strong guidance on, on rates and on asset purchases that’s providing very strong support for economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at the sectors of the economy that are interest sensitive, you will see very strong activity: housing, durable goods, automobile sales.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, our, our policies are working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think that, that they are—we think our policy stance is, is right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That said, there’s clearly more that we can do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With asset purchases, for example, we can, you know—that’s, that’s a tool we can do more—we can strengthen our guidance, too, if we were to think that that were appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What you see is an economy where what’s holding it back is not the lack of, of policy support from the Fed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, it’s the spread of the disease and people’s reluctance or, or inability to partake in certain kinds of economic activities, which amount to a, a meaningful part of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s what I would say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We certainly have things that we can do, but we think we’re—we think we’re in the right place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, in terms of—in terms of tapering, it’s just premature.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We just created the, the guidance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We said we’d want to see substantial further progress toward our goals before we modify our, our asset purchase guidance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just too early to be talking about dates, which we should be focused on, on progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll need to see actual progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And when, when we see ourselves getting to that point, we’ll communicate clearly about it to, to the public so nobody will be surprised when the time comes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll do that well in advance of actually considering what will be a pretty gradual taper.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, I, I was here—we had all the same questions back in—after the Global Financial Crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We raised interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We froze the balance sheet size, and then we shrank the balance sheet size.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s no reason why we, we won’t be able to do that again.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In fact, we learned a lot from that experience.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we, we understand—as we understood then, but even more so—we understand that the—that the way to do it is to communicate well in advance, to, to do predictable things, and to move gradually.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s, that’s what we’re going to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to be very transparent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, honestly, no—you know, the whole focus on exit is premature, if I may say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re focused on finishing the job we’re doing, which is to support the economy, to give the economy the support it needs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are people out there who’ve lost their jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s essential that we get them back to work as quickly as possible, and we want to do everything we can to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that is our primary focus right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, it’s, it’s too soon to be—to be worried about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, when we come to exit, we have a—we have an understanding of how to do that, and we’ll do it very carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But in the meantime, our focus is on giving the economy the support it needs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I would say that, again, we have been struggling with disinflationary forces for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look around the world—look in Western Europe, look at Japan—around the world, large economies have, have felt much more downward pressure on inflation, have fallen short of their inflation goals, for some time now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is the broad global macroeconomic context that we all live in.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we believe that those global forces—which are, you know, aging demographics, advancing technology, and globalization—those, those forces are still in effect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, they may slow down, and, and it’s, it’s an interesting question, the extent to which, for example, globalization may slow down or even reverse.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Notwithstanding that, inflation dynamics in the United States have, have consisted of a flat Phillips curve and low persistence for, for a long time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do not expect in the near term that that will change significantly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It may evolve over time, but significant time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, these things are—these things are, are changing, but they don’t change at a rapid rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there’s—I, I don’t believe that, that they will.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I wouldn’t—I’m, I’m not—I’m much more worried about falling short of a complete recovery and losing people’s careers and lives that they—that they built because they don’t get to work—back to work in time and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m more concerned about that and the damage that will do not just to their lives, but to the United States economy, to the productive capacity of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m more concerned about that than about the possibility, which exists, of higher inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Frankly, we welcome slightly higher inflation, somewhat higher inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The kind of troubling inflation that people like me grew up with seems, seems far away and unlikely in, in the both domestic and global context that we’ve been in for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I have the highest respect and admiration for Secretary Yellen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’m, I’m sure that we’re going to have a, a good working relationship together.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Absolutely sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll also have a good institutional relationship between the Fed and the Treasury.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I expect that that’ll be very good and, and very productive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’ll be collaborative.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll work together.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, the way that works is, is that, you know, we know—the agencies know each other well, and this is true of finance ministries and central banks around the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know to stay in our lanes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know we have different authorities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know that we work together on some things to—you know, for the benefit of the public.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’m, I’m absolutely sure that we’re going to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, you know, haven’t—I haven’t spoken to, to Secretary Yellen—I’m going to be calling her “Chair Yellen” most of the time, so you just have to be patient with me—Secretary Yellen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I haven’t spoken to her since I congratulated her on being nominated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do expect very soon to begin our regular calls or—and, and ultimately meetings, which have gone on, really, for, you know, 70 years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Treasury Secretary and the, and the Fed Chair have had weekly or so meetings, lunches, breakfast, calls, depending on the situation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I expect that will—that will happen soon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ve—I have not met the, the President, President Biden.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And just, you know, I, I, I don’t—I don’t have any comment on your—on your last question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t want to comment one way or the other.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I—I’ll just say that I think our facilities were very successful in supporting the economy during its darkest moments and I believe saved—protected the loss of millions of jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to continue to monitor financial and credit conditions throughout the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and if the kind of emergency conditions arise that are required under that law, then our emergency lending tools will remain available.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, I’ve had no discussions with anybody at Treasury on that, because I haven’t had any discussions with anybody at Treasury other than meet—you know, high-level meetings with the—with the transition team a month or so ago.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And once we start having those, those meetings, of course, I’ll observe, you know, the long-standing practice of not talking about confidential discussions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But as of now, there haven’t been any discussions at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So in the statement, on the language, we dropped “in the medium term,” because, really, the risks are, are in the near term, frankly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, as I mentioned, it’s the rollout of the vaccine.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s the arrival of new strains that, that are more contagious and perhaps more virulent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And those are the—those are the—and also just the ongoing—third thing, of course, is the ongoing spread of the virus.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, it’s in the near term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not in the medium term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We were thinking—when we were thinking “medium term,” we were thinking of longer-term scarring and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, I mean, I think what—to go to your, your second question, and as I mentioned in my, in my opening remarks—there is good evidence to, to support a stronger economy in the second half of this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right across the board: much higher forecasts for 2021 growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s because of the ongoing rollout of the vaccines and also because of fiscal policy, expectations, and the reality of, of the CRRA Act [Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021] getting done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there is—there is a positive case there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that—think of that as—the sort of base case is, is a strong economy in the second half of the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The language says that there’s still—I forget the exact language—downside risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We used an adjective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It was “considerable”—“considerable risks to the economic outlook.” So there are considerable risks, risks to the economic outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, that is—that is a more positive outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s really how, how I would—I would parse that for you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t know when we’re going to come back to work, and I’m, I’m actually in the Eccles Building here today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I don’t know when that’ll be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, we—I can’t wait to be working in person again.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, we—we’ve been able to work successfully remotely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We really have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’re not going to push people when they’re uncomfortable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to wait till people are comfortable and wait till it’s well and truly time to get back together in person.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re, we’re monitoring that on an ongoing basis, continue to—continuing to evaluate our, our restrictions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we haven’t made a decision about whether to continue them in the second quarter or not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re just going to look at bank—we’re going to look at the whole range of, of information, including economic activity, banking activity, the, the success in vaccination.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All of those things will go into our assessment of what the right answer is to that question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we’ve been careful about, about rolling back those restrictions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and I’m pleased with where we are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let’s remember that the banks—that the banks that are subject to the stress tests have taken very, very large reserves—very large loss reserves, and also increased their capital.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’ve actually had—they have higher capital ratios now than they had at the beginning of the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the banking system has held up well here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and—but, you know, we’re going to be careful about this and, you know, move based on data, and all of the data, when we make that decision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on housing, you know, housing is now—the level of housing activity is at its highest level since before the Global Financial Crisis, in some measures.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ve had a very strong rebound in housing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Some of the, the tightness in housing markets, we think—which has led to the, the significant price increases this year—we think is, is a passing phenomenon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There was a lot of pent-up demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a one-time thing happening with people who are spending all of their time in their house, and they’re thinking either “I need a bigger house” or “I need another house and a different house—or a second house,” in some cases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s just—there’s a—there’s a one-time shift in demand that we think will get satisfied—also, that will call forth supply.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that will—that will, we think—we think that those price increases are unlikely to be sustained for, for all of those reasons.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we, we monitor pretty much all of the big financial markets pretty carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, what’s happened in, in the corporate debt market, beginning with the announcement of our corporate credit facility, has been, you’ve seen lenders lending and borrowers borrowing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’ve seen relatively significantly fewer defaults than we—than we expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There were a lot of downgrades and some defaults at the beginning, and those have really slowed down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, the same is true for bank loans.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Banks are not experiencing the kinds of defaults that, that we all were concerned about in the early months of the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just not materializing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So they’re having to reverse some of their loss reserves, actually.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Debts—corporate debt spreads are, are tight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’ve tightened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They were very broad—high—wide, of course, at the—during the acute phase of the pandemic, and they’ve—you know, they’re now at the lower end of their typical range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we do monitor that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it’s, it’s not something we can control or operate on directly, but we do—we do watch those things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, in a sense, it’s good that companies have been able to finance themselves during this period, because they—they’ve been able to stay in business.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’ve been able to keep their employees working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, that’s a good thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s, that’s part of highly accommodative financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the, the, the big thing is that the jury’s out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And this has been a concern since the very beginning, is the concern that people—if, if they become disconnected from the industry or the job where—that they used to work in, it, it can be years or never when they get back into the labor force, particularly for people who are well along in their careers—the same kind of scarring for small businesses, which don’t have the kind of resources that you need to get through this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ve, we’ve had a big concern about, about both of those.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven’t seen as much of it as we—as we feared.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s a good thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But as I said that, you know, the jury is out here—9 or 10 million people still out of work because of the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re—a big chunk of them are people who worked in public-facing jobs in the service sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, they’ve gotten a lot of support from fiscal policy and some from monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the question is getting them back to work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, it’s, it’s harder if you’re—it takes longer, empirically, to find that next job if you’re looking at a brand-new industry.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not easy to change careers completely midcareer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that just, again, stresses the urgency that we feel and others feel at, at, you know, fully defeating the pandemic, finishing the job and getting back to a place where it’s safe to have these—you know, to, to, to stay in hotels, to fly on airplanes, to go to sporting events and movie theaters, and all of those things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So those people are still at risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re, we’re very, very focused on that group of people with our policy and, and, and, you know, the way we look at the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So many people have had that bridge across the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we talked about that at the beginning.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For many people, it’s clear that they’ve made it across, and their job is okay, and their house is okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, it’s been terribly inconvenient and painful, and schools are closed and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But there, there’s a bunch of people yet who haven’t found that bridge yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re, we’re very focused on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, the other thing is, we’re going to a different economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re going to be learning more about that as we go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, clearly, we’re, we’re learning that things can be done from remote locations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re learning that technology can replace people even more than we thought.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And some of that is happening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think as we, you know, as we get into this, you know, the phase after—even after the economy fully reopens, I think we’re still going to need to keep people in mind whose lives have been disrupted, because they’ve lost that—the work that they did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think it would be wise as a country, for the longer-run productive capacity of the country, if we were to look out for those people and help them find their way back into the labor force even if it means continuing support for an additional period of time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I strongly agree with that, as a matter of fact.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think if you look at either—look at employment gaps or unemployment gaps or wage gaps, wealth gaps, homeowning gaps, all of those persistent gaps that exist even controlling for many other factors, you will see that they’re, they’re persistent, they’re—and they’re very difficult to explain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so it’s—the reason we talk about inequality and, and racial inequality in particular, is that it goes to our job, which is to achieve maximum employment, which, which links up with, with—we want—we want the potential output of the United States to be as high as it can possibly be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want—we want an economy where everybody can take part and everybody, everybody can put their labor in, and they can share in the prosperity of our great economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what we want.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s how the U.S. economy can be bigger, stronger, growing faster, is if we can achieve a more—a broader prosperity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, now, in terms of our tools, you know, of course, that project that I just mentioned is one for the broader society, for the private sector, for fiscal policy, but we have a role to play.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and that is, how we think about the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Principally, when we say that the maximum employment is a, a broad and inclusive goal, what we’re—what we’re saying there is, we’re not just going to look at the headline—and we never did, really, but—we’re not going to just look at the headline numbers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to look at different demographic groups, including women, minorities, and others.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re not going to say that we’ve reached maximum employment, which is our statutory goal, until we’ve reached maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you haven’t if, if there’s lots of pockets of, of people not participating in or not employed in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So those are the things that we can do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also do a tremendous amount of research on these issues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we do—we, we have such a focus on these issues now that we actually—we, we have a new, a webpage, relatively new, where you can access all of it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s a lot of activities in our Division of Consumer and Community Affairs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s lots of research, and, and it’s also, you know, our enforcement of the fair lending laws and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think everybody’s got a role to play here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a—it’s a national goal and a national job, and we’re just going to do our part of the job.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s something we’re strongly committed to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think, if you go back to the—to the beginning, there was a real concern.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, just, just take the financial markets, for example.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Suddenly, all of those big buildings all over the, the—New York City and all around the world where people work in the financial markets with terminals and everything, everybody had to go home, and they had to take their terminals with them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think there was a real concern that there would be a tremendous loss of functionality just at the time when the financial markets were under historically difficult conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And yet, it worked out okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think people—many people in the financial sector are still working with their terminals at home, including people on trading floors or on virtual trading floors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, some of that’s reversing now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we have definitely learned that we can do more work from home in many, many different lines of work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, that’s not possible if your job involves being at a place, doing personal services.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For many people, it’s not possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s very much something that skews to higher-income, higher-educated people being able to work from home and others not so much.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think we’ve learned that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The other thing, though, even conditional on that, when we saw the wave in the South and the West, the wave of cases this summer, I think, intuitively, having seen what happened in March and April, we expected there to be a significant hit to economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And people kind of just got on with their lives and went and, and dealt with it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and it didn’t actually—it had a much smaller effect on economic activity than we expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Then comes the fall wave, which is just so much larger—a very, very large wave as, as was very much forecast.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People going indoors, the cold weather, all of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And even there, if you look at—I would say, look at the December jobs report.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, big job losses in, you know, in that part of the service sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I mentioned 400,000 jobs in bars and restaurants.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s another 100,000 in similar kinds of activities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But if you go—if you look elsewhere, it’s not having an effect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, even purchasing manager index and sentiment indexes on, on areas of the economy that are not directly—really directly—exposed to the pandemic in their economic activity, they’re doing okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Housing is a great example.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the way—the way—the way the housing industry worked, that when you buy a house, there was a lot of in-person contact.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They managed to pretty much immediately go to a more virtual—you know, with all the technology.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They were able to completely avoid that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the housing market has been really strong, notwithstanding that it’s, it’s now quite virtual rather than in person.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s been a lot of adapting, and—but you can’t adapt, you know, hotels, sporting venues, movie theaters, restaurants, bars.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You just—you know, those are just going to—and that’s—again, that’s millions and millions of people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so you’re just going to have to defeat the pandemic, which, as I mentioned, you know, we, we have a plan to do that, but we haven’t done it yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we need to—we need to finish the job.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we—it’s, it’s within our power to do that as a country this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would just urge that—and I know people are working hard on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that, that is really the main thing about the economy, is, is getting the pandemic under control, getting everyone vaccinated, getting people wearing masks, and all that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s the single most important economic growth policy that we can have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.
